questions.text: A 55-year-old man with a history of obesity and obstructive sleep apnea is scheduled for elective surgery. During the preoperative assessment, the anesthesiologist evaluates the patient's airway to predict the potential difficulty of intubation. Which of the following test is considered the most predictive for a difficult intubation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Upper lip bite test

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Option A. Mallampati classification: Mallampati classification relates the visibility of structures in the oral cavity with the tongue protruding; a higher class can indicate a potentially difficult airway.
  • • Option
  • • A. Mallampati classification:
  • • Option B. Thyromental distance: It measures the distance from the thyroid notch to the mentum; a shorter distance can suggest a difficult airway due to anatomical constraints.
  • • Option
  • • B. Thyromental distance:
  • • Option D. Sternomental distance : It measures the distance from the sternum to the mentum with the head extended; a smaller distance can be associated with a difficult airway.
  • • Option
  • • D. Sternomental distance

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Upper lip bite test is a reliable and simple bedside test to predict difficult intubation; it evaluates both the mandibular space and the patient's ability to move the jaw and neck, which are crucial for intubation.
  • ➤ The Upper lip bite test is a reliable and simple bedside test to predict difficult intubation; it evaluates both the mandibular space and the patient's ability to move the jaw and neck, which are crucial for intubation.

He also has erythema and swelling of his hands and feet, and desquamation of the fingers. There is no history of cough or rhinorrhea. Laboratory results show elevated inflammatory markers. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis seen in children and is characterized by prolonged fever, conjunctival injection, changes in the oral mucosa, a polymorphous rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy. It is essential to recognize and treat Kawasaki disease promptly to prevent coronary artery aneurysms.
  • ➤ Kawasaki disease is an acute vasculitis seen in children and is characterized by prolonged fever, conjunctival injection, changes in the oral mucosa, a polymorphous rash, extremity changes, and cervical lymphadenopathy.
  • ➤ It is essential to recognize and treat Kawasaki disease promptly to prevent coronary artery aneurysms.

questions.text: A 68-year-old male with a history of congestive heart failure is admitted to the hospital and is on diuretic therapy for the same, but reports reduced urine output over the last two days. On admission, his serum creatinine is 2.0 mg/dL, up from a baseline of 1.2 mg/dL one month ago. He has a urine output of 300 mL in the first 6 hours after admission. What stage of acute kidney injury (AKI) does this patient's presentation most likely correspond to?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stage 1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stage 1 acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined by a 1.5-1.9 times increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days or a urine output of <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6-12 hours, according to the KDIGO criteria.
  • ➤ Stage 1 acute kidney injury (AKI) is defined by a 1.5-1.9 times increase in serum creatinine from baseline within 7 days or a urine output of <0.5 mL/kg/hour for 6-12 hours, according to the KDIGO criteria.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presents with progressive dyspnea and fatigue over 2 years. Physical exam reveals pedal edema, jugular venous distention, and hepatomegaly, with clear lung fields. Chest CT shows right heart enlargement. Cardiac catheterization reveals increased pulmonary arterial pressure without valve gradients or shunts. A transbronchial biopsy shows plexiform lesions with smooth muscle hypertrophy and luminal narrowing. Which of the following genetic mutations is most likely responsible?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Bone morphogenetic receptor 2 (BMPR2)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mutations in the BMPR2 gene are the most common genetic cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension, leading to abnormal proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and characteristic pathological findings such as plexiform lesions.
  • ➤ Mutations in the BMPR2 gene are the most common genetic cause of pulmonary arterial hypertension, leading to abnormal proliferation of vascular smooth muscle cells and characteristic pathological findings such as plexiform lesions.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman is considering permanent contraception. Which of the following methods is NOT performed using an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Essure

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Essure is a hysteroscopic method of tubal occlusion, not an abdominal laparoscopic technique. It involves placing a small metal coil into the fallopian tubes via the vagina and cervix. Over time, this induces fibrosis and occludes the tubes, preventing pregnancy.
  • • Essure is a hysteroscopic method of tubal occlusion, not an abdominal laparoscopic technique.
  • • It involves placing a small metal coil into the fallopian tubes via the vagina and cervix.
  • • Over time, this induces fibrosis and occludes the tubes, preventing pregnancy.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Pomeroy: This is a common laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation where a loop of the fallopian tube is tied off and a segment is removed.
  • • Option A. Pomeroy:
  • • Option B. Parkland: This technique involves tying and cutting the fallopian tubes at two separate points and removing the segment in between, and it can be performed laparoscopically.
  • • Option B. Parkland:
  • • Option C. Irving: This laparoscopic technique involves ligating the tube and then burying the ends in the myometrium, thus preventing re-canalization.
  • • Option C. Irving:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Essure is not an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation; it is a hysteroscopic method. In contrast, Pomeroy, Parkland, and Irving techniques are all abdominal laparoscopic methods used for tubal ligation.
  • ➤ Essure is not an abdominal laparoscopic technique for tubal ligation; it is a hysteroscopic method. In contrast, Pomeroy, Parkland, and Irving techniques are all abdominal laparoscopic methods used for tubal ligation.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman has had diarrhea, fatigue, and a 3-kg weight loss over 6 months. She is afebrile with mild muscle wasting but normal motor strength. Lab studies show no occult blood, ova, or parasites in the stool. Upper jejunal biopsy shows specific changes, and she improves dramatically on a gluten-free diet. What microscopic feature is most likely seen in her biopsy?

options.label: C
options.text: Foamy macrophages within the lamina propria

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Villous blunting and flattening

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Villous blunting and flattening in the small intestine biopsy is the characteristic microscopic feature of celiac disease, which improves with a gluten-free diet.
  • ➤ Villous blunting and flattening in the small intestine biopsy is the characteristic microscopic feature of celiac disease, which improves with a gluten-free diet.

questions.text: A 24-year-old swimmer presents with sudden onset of fever, headache, nausea, and neck stiffness. After a few days, the patient develops confusion and seizures. The microscopic slide of CSF is shown below. Based on the clinical presentation and microscopic findings, which of the following organisms is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Naegleria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ FREE-LIVING AMOEBAE
  • ➤ FREE-LIVING AMOEBAE
  • ➤ Free-living amoebae are small, freely living, widely distributed in soil and water and can cause opportunistic infections in humans. Human pathogens are:
  • ➤ Naegleria fowleri is a causative agent of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM). Acanthamoeba species causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE) and amoebic keratitis in contact lens wearers. Balamuthia mandrillaris causes GAE. Sappinia species: causes encephalitis.
  • ➤ Naegleria fowleri is a causative agent of primary amoebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).
  • ➤ Acanthamoeba species causes granulomatous amoebic encephalitis (GAE) and amoebic keratitis in contact lens wearers.
  • ➤ Balamuthia mandrillaris causes GAE.
  • ➤ Sappinia species: causes encephalitis.

questions.text: In a clinical setting, a physician evaluates a middle-aged man experiencing episodes of rapid heartbeat. To assess the impact of parasympathetic nervous system activity on his cardiac function, the physician administers a vagal stimulation test. What change in the ECG would be indicative of effective vagal stimulation?
questions.correct_answer: D. Increased R-R interval in ECG
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased R-R interval in ECG

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Increased vagal stimulation leads to a longer R-R interval on an ECG, reflecting a decrease in heart rate. This effect is a key aspect of the parasympathetic influence on cardiac function.
  • ➤ Increased vagal stimulation leads to a longer R-R interval on an ECG, reflecting a decrease in heart rate.
  • ➤ This effect is a key aspect of the parasympathetic influence on cardiac function.

questions.text: Assertion (A): Floaters are common in young myopes. Reason (B): With increasing age, vitreous gel liquefies.

options.label: A
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements and the Reason is the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: B
options.text: Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

options.label: C
options.text: Assertion is independently true statement, but the Reason is independently false statement

options.label: D
options.text: Assertion is independently false statement, but the Reason is independently true statement

questions.correct_answer: B. Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Both Assertion and Reason are independently true statements, but the Reason is not the correct explanation for the Assertion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Both floaters being common in young myopes and the age-related liquefaction of the vitreous gel are true, but they are not causally connected in the way described. Understanding these independent processes is important for accurate clinical assessment and patient education about visual symptoms.
  • ➤ Both floaters being common in young myopes and the age-related liquefaction of the vitreous gel are true, but they are not causally connected in the way described.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with urinary incontinence and recurrent urinary tract infections. Imaging studies reveal a vesicovaginal fistula.
